Project Description  The  Project  affirms  the  Government’s  commitment  to  promote  the 
inclusive socioeconomic development of the most disadvantaged groups, 
particularly  ethnic  minorities  and  girls,  in  103  of  the  poorest  districts  in 
Viet Nam, through universal lower secondary education.  
 
The Project will improve access to more equitable learning opportunities 
for  disadvantaged  groups  and  will  strengthen  social  and  economic 
inclusion through universal secondary education. Specifically, the Project 
will  (i)  improve  access  to  lower  secondary  education,  (ii)  enhance  the

innovative  approaches  to  give  disadvantaged  groups  better  access  to 
education,  and  (iv)  strengthen  capacity  to  plan  and  manage  targeted 
support for ethnic minorities and girls.

Assumptions 
 
 

 

Improved  access  to  secondary  education  will  directly  benefit  the  entire 
lower  secondary  education-eligible  cohort  in  the  103  target  districts 
(totaling about 700,000 children aged 11–14). The direct benefits to the 
sector  will  accrue  from  (i)  significantly  narrower  gaps  in  access  to 
secondary  schooling  between  ethnic,  gender,  and  socioeconomic 
groups;  (ii) teaching  and  learning  that  is  more  relevant  and  more 
responsive  to  local  demands;  and  (iii)  stronger  capacity  of  local 
education authorities to plan, manage, and deliver education services. 
 
Key  social  benefits  will  include  (i)  better  awareness  of  the  benefits  of 
lower  secondary  schooling  among  minority  commune  leaders  and 
parents; (ii) improved participation of girls in lower secondary education; 
(iii)  more  ethnic  minority  youth  able  to  find  nonfarm  employment, 
resulting in higher average household incomes; (iv) more ethnic minority 
teachers,  particularly  women,  serving  as  role  models  for  ethnic  minority 
students;  (v) a  stable  supply  of  qualified  teachers  to  remote  minority 
schools  to  help  preserve  minority  languages  and  culture;  and  (vi) 
continuing education opportunities for out-of-school youth. 
 
Project  risks  could  come  from  (i)  low  demand  for  secondary  education 
among  the  hardest-to-reach  groups,  (ii)  high  teacher  turnover,  (iii)  low 
financial sustainability in the medium term, and (iv) resettlement.  
 
A  key  assumption  is  that  all  civil  works  will  be  done  on  existing  school 
grounds  or  on  government-owned  land,  and  that  no  land  acquisition  or 
resettlement  will  be  necessary.  To  mitigate  the  risk,  a  resettlement 
framework has been developed in accordance with Government Decree 
No.  197/2004/ND-CP  (2004)  regarding  compensation,  assistance  and 
resettlement where land is recovered by the state and ADB’s Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy (1995). 
 
One  of  the  risks  of  an  education  project  that  strives  to  reach  the  most 
excluded students with new school buildings and physical facilities is that 
demand for education will remain low. To mitigate this risk, the Project is 
designed to balance interventions on the supply side—new classrooms, 
training for teaching staff, etc.—with activities on the demand side such 
as  scholarships,  school  feeding  programs,  and  community  awareness 
activities.  In  remote  schools  in  the  poorest  areas,  where  teacher 
retention rates are low, the Project attempts to deal with one of the main 
reasons why teachers leave, namely, poor-quality teacher housing. 
 
A drop in the recurrent budget allocations for operation and maintenance 
and teachers’ salaries is a medium-term risk, in view of the revenue-poor 
districts  and  disadvantaged  students  targeted  by  the  Project.  However, 
analysis indicates the Government’s sustained commitment to education 
in  budgetary  allocation.  In  2006,  20%  of  public  expenditure  went  to 
education.  While  the  sector  will  most  likely  continue  to  be  a  priority  for 
the  Government,  as  set  out  in  SEDP  2006–2010,  special  assistance 
programs  for  targeted  districts  and  disadvantaged  students  should  hold 
firm for the targets related to universal lower secondary education to be 
achieved and project investments to be sustainable.

Indicators and Analysis of Performance

2. 
Viet Nam has enjoyed remarkable economic growth accompanied by significant income 
poverty reduction over the past decade. Gross domestic product per capita increased from $288 
in 1993 to $622 in 2004. The incidence of income poverty fell from 58% in 1993 to 23% in 2004 
as  broad-based  reforms  after  doi  moi  (renewal)  led  to  vigorous  growth  with  diversified 
employment opportunities, greater macroeconomic and political stability, and targeted programs 
to provide basic public infrastructure and services. With this overwhelmingly positive transition, 
however, has come socioeconomic polarization. From being widespread throughout the general 
population, poverty has become concentrated among specific vulnerable groups that are much 
harder to reach. The incidence of poverty is 18% nationwide and only 14% in urban areas, but it 
is a much higher 26% in rural areas. Regional disparities are striking: the incidence of poverty in 
the Northwest region was 52% in 2004, compared with just 6% in the Southeast region. Poverty 
levels  in  the  Northeast  (29%)  and  Central  Highlands  (33%)  regions  were  also  well  above  the 
national average.1 
 
3. 
Ethnic  minorities—12  million  in  all,  or  about  14%  of  the  population  of  Viet  Nam—are 
particularly  vulnerable  to  poverty.  Ethno-linguistically,  they  represent  a  diverse  range  of 
53 minorities  that  live  mostly  in  the  remote  mountainous  areas  and  lowland  river  deltas.  The 
poorest  areas  of  Viet  Nam  tend  to  have  a  high  concentration  of  ethnic  minorities.  In  2004, 
minorities  composed  39%  of  the  population  living  in  poverty,  and  61%  of  all  ethnic  minority 
people were poor (as opposed to only 14% of the majority Kinh and Chinese).2 The proportion 
of ethnic minorities in the poor population has nearly doubled in 11 years. If these trends persist, 
by 2010 poverty will be overwhelmingly an issue of ethnicity.3 
 
Poverty  among  minority  groups  is  closely  associated  with  low  or  limited  access  to 
4. 
education  and  training  opportunities.  The  main  reasons  are  lack  of  infrastructure,  physical 
distance,  language  and  cultural  barriers,  the  small  number  and  poor  quality  of  teachers, 
unsuitability  of  the  curriculum  to  local  needs,  low  investment  in  education  because  of  the 
perceived  low  returns,  and  high  opportunity  costs.  Enrollment  and  completion  rates  for 
minorities  are  generally  below  the  average,  and  for  minority  girls  they  are  even  lower.  In  the 
2005 school year, girls made up 48% of lower secondary students nationwide. In the Northwest, 
where 82% of lower secondary students come from minorities, less than 44% of these students 
are girls. Dropout rates tend to be higher for minorities. In 2004–2005, the dropout rate for the 
Mekong River Delta region was 13%, almost twice the national average of 7%.

While  the  country  has  made  solid  progress  toward  achieving  the  MDGs  and  VDGs,

The  low  level  of  human  capital  among  minorities  is  a  critical  challenge.  In  response,  the 
Government has issued a decree that specifically directs special assistance programs to the 18 
smallest ethnic minority groups.5

The national education and training system extends from nursery school to postgraduate 
doctoral programs, and comprises both formal and nonformal and continuing education. There 
are  four  levels  of  formal  education:  pre-primary,  primary  (grades  1–5),  lower  secondary 
(grades 6–9),  and  upper  secondary  (grades  10–12).  At  the  upper  secondary  level,  students 
either enroll in upper secondary education (USE) and possibly continue to higher education, or 
opt  for  professional  secondary  education  and  vocational  training.  Continuing  education 
programs cater to students who drop out of school but wish to continue their education in a less 
formal  setting  or  hope  to  qualify  for  re-enrollment  in  formal  education.  These  nationwide 
programs use a modified curriculum and take place at continuing education centers (CECs) in 
the provinces and districts. 
 
11. 
The Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) has overall responsibility for setting the 
broad  policy  direction  for  all  levels  of  education.  Responsibility  for  managing  school  buildings, 
staffing,  and  distribution  of  financial  resources  is  progressively  decentralized.  MOET  manages 
the  universities  directly,  but  has  delegated  the  management  of  upper  secondary  and 
professional  secondary  schools  to  the  provincial  departments  of  education  and  training 
(DOETs),  and  lower  secondary  and  primary  schools  to  the  district  bureaus  of  education  and 
training  (BOETs).  Education  sector  spending  in  relation  to  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  has 
risen,  from  3.5%  in  1994  to  4.6%  in  2004.  Compared  with  other  sectors,  education  receives 
priority, its share of public expenditure increasing to 20% in 2006.8 
 
12. 
The  Government  passed  a  new  education  law  in  June  2005  to  improve  the  quality  of 
education and make it more generally accessible. The law outlines the goals and principles of 
education. In addition, these supporting policy documents guide decision making for the sector: 
(i) the  Education  Strategic  Development  Plan  2001–2010,  (iii)  the  National  Action  Plan  for 
Education for All (NAPEFA) 2003–2015, (iii) the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth 
Strategy, and (iv) the Secondary Education Sector Master Plan (SESMP) 2006–2010.9  
 
13. 
The  Secondary  Education  Sector  Master  Plan  2006–2010.  Despite  steadily 
increasing  enrollment  rates,  MOET  realizes  that  achieving  universal  LSE  requires  a  more

MOET  therefore  developed  the  SESMP  2006–2010  in  2006,  with  assistance  from  the  Asian

The review of the secondary education subsector based on the SESMP 2006–2010 has 
identified the following problems in access and equity, quality and relevance, and efficiency and

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Challenges in the Secondary Education Subsector 

a. 

Access and Equity 

 
16. 
Low Access.  The high enrollment rate of 83% in lower secondary school is a national 
average  that  masks  disparities  in  access  and  quality  of  schooling  by  gender,  ethnic,  regional, 
and socioeconomic status. Only 34 out of 64 provinces have achieved universal LSE. In some 
provinces,  the  disparities  are  widening.  Innovative  and  targeted  assistance  is  needed  to  bring 
the most difficult-to-reach groups, such as ethnic minorities and girls in the poorest communes, 
into the education system.  
 
Physical distance is the main obstacle to school enrollment and participation, especially 
17. 
in  remote  rural  areas.  In  the  Northern  Mountain  and  Central  Highland  regions,  it  can  take 
students the better part of a day to walk to school in very mountainous terrain. In the Mekong 
River  Delta,  students  travel  to  school  by  boat  and  on  foot  but  are  often  kept  from  attending 
school by flooding. Remote areas have limited semi-boarding facilities, where students can stay 
during  the  week,  but  most  are  severely  inadequate.  The  demand  for  such  facilities  in  minority 
areas  is  high,  despite  their  poor  condition,  and  far  exceeds  the  supply.  In  their  absence, 
students resort to staying in private homes, usually in exchange for physical labor or a nominal 
rent.  Both  lower  secondary  schools  (LSSs)  and  CECs  do  not  have  enough  classrooms  to 
absorb the ethnic minority youth. More schools and CECs and secure semi-boarding facilities in 
rural remote areas will relieve the constraints on access. 
 
18. 
Financial and Cultural Barriers. Households incur substantial direct and indirect costs 
for  education,  including  school  fees  and  the  cost  of  textbooks,  materials,  uniforms,  food,  and 
transportation,  all  of  which  combine  to  hinder  school  enrollment  among  poor  families.  A  large 
part of the opportunity cost of education, which increases at the LSE level, is the loss of child 
labor from household production. Poor families, for this reason, are held back from investing in 
the  education  of  their  children,  particularly  daughters,  for  whom  the  opportunity  costs  are 
greater.  The  contribution  of  the  child  to  the  family  income  may  be  more  important  to  the 
household  in  the  short  term.  Primary  pupils  from  the  poorest  quintile  of  the  population  work 
twice  as  long  as  students  from  the  richest  quintile,  and  female  students  work  20–50%  longer 
hours  than  males  across  all  income  quintiles  and  ethnic  groups.  There  is  a  need  for  more 
focused  measurements  of  the  financial  burden  of  direct  education  costs  on  poor  families  and 
innovative awareness-raising programs to promote the longer-term benefits of investing in their 
children’s secondary education.

Language  Barriers.  Lack  of  fluency  in  the  Vietnamese  language  also  limits  the 
participation  rate  of  minority  students.11 A  recent  UNICEF  ethno-linguistic  study  found  a  close

the  consequent  grade  repetitions  and  dropouts.12 Many  minority  children  with  little  or  no  prior 
exposure  to  the  Vietnamese  language  have  difficulty  understanding  lessons.  In  the  northern 
uplands  in  particular,  this  situation  can  be  heightened  by  the  confusing  mix  of  minority 
languages spoken in the same classroom and by teachers who have not been trained to teach 
in a multilingual and multicultural environment. To address this issue, methods of teaching in a 
multicultural environment and of teaching Vietnamese to ethnic minority students must be made 
part of pre-service teacher training. 
 
20. 
Gender  Disparities. A gender imbalance in educational attainment persists. There are 
fewer  girls  than  boys  enrolled  at  all  levels  of  the  education  system  except  in  professional 
secondary education. A small but significant gender gap in enrollment in both primary education 
and LSE has not improved significantly over the last 5 years.13 Mean years of schooling offer a 
stark  illustration  of  this  gap:  on  average,  girls  complete  only  5.6  years  of  schooling  compared 
with  6.8  years  for  boys.  This  gap  widens  dramatically  when  ethnicity  is  factored  in:  Kinh  boys 
achieve  8.5  mean  years  of  schooling,  compared  with  just  4.5  years  for  ethnic  minority  girls. 
Improved,  girl-friendly  school  facilities  and  programs  aimed  at  making  parents  more  aware  of 
the benefits of educating their daughters will help reduce this imbalance.  
 
Out-of-School  Youth.  Dropout  rates  are  highest  in  the  provinces  where  relatively 
21. 
well-paid  unskilled  work  is  readily  available.  In  some  provinces  in  the  Mekong  River  Delta—
where tourism and garments are growth industries—families often consider sending children to 
work rather than to school as a more profitable option. In some provinces an estimated 20% of 
11-  to  14-year-olds  do  seasonal  work  in  the  factories  in  neighboring  provinces.  Motivating 
overage youth dropouts to reenter the formal school system is hard . In such cases, CECs can 
provide  alternative  learning  opportunities.  Continuing  education  can  be  better  tailored  to  meet 
their  needs  for  vocational  and  life  skills  while  earning  them  a  secondary  leaving  certificate, 
which may even induce them to rejoin the formal education system later on. CECs in poor areas 
are  currently  limited  in  number,  and  many  suffer  from  overcrowding.  More  CEC  facilities  are 
needed to ease the overcrowding and improve access for out-of-school youth. 
 

b. 

Quality and Relevance 

 
22. 
Poor Quality of Teaching. Real improvement in student learning will occur and become 
sustainable  only  when  teachers  are  fully  trained,  prepared,  and  supported  through  the 
complexities  of  teaching  ethnic  minority  students.  But  ethnic  minority  schools  in  remote  areas 
tend  to  suffer  even  more  than  schools  elsewhere  in  the  country  from  poor-quality  teaching, 
limited  learning  resources,  high  teacher  absenteeism,  and  rapid  turnover  of  staff.  While  the 
teachers  generally  have  good  knowledge  and  the  majority  are  certified,  they  have  significant 
weaknesses  in  practical  teaching  skills.  These  weaknesses  are  due  to  such  factors  as  the 
following:  (i)  an  intense  focus  on  the  acquisition  of  knowledge  at  the  expense  of  teaching 
methods  in  both  pre-service  teacher  training  (PRESETT)  and  in-service  teacher  training 
(INSETT), (ii) culturally and linguistically inappropriate education, (iii) gender and ethnicity bias 
in  instructional  materials,  and  (iv)  a  lack  of  effective  strategies  for  motivating  young  teachers 
struggling in difficult teaching environments and providing them with long-term career paths.

Limited Learning Materials and Facilities. An effective learning environment requires 
24. 
well-equipped  facilities—such  as  libraries  and  science  laboratories—and  enough  good-quality 
learning  materials  that  match  the  needs  and  interests  of  ethnic  minority  students  and  girls.

c. 

Efficiency and Sustainability 

 
25. 
Low  Retention,  High  Repetition  and  Dropout  Rates.  The  average  number  of  years 
needed to complete LSE in 2004 was 4.8 nationwide, but 5.7 in the Mekong River Delta, 5.0 in 
the  Central  Highlands, and  5.3  on  average  for  ethnic  minorities.  The  average  LSS  completion 
rate that same year was 76% for the country as a whole but only 58% in the Mekong River Delta 
(footnote 6). These figures highlight the lower efficiency of services in remote areas. Minorities 
compose 14% of enrollment in LSE and 12% in USE—roughly equivalent to their overall share 
of  the  population.  However,  at  both  lower  and  upper  secondary  levels  overage  enrollment  is 
likely to be significant as minorities in remote areas often delay enrolling their children in primary 
school because of the long distances they must travel to school.  
 
26. 
For minority students, repetition rates at the primary level are higher, leading to overage 
entry  into  LSE,  and  correct-age  enrollment  is  likely  to  be  lower  than  the  total  figures. 
Nationwide,  the  minority  population  aged  11–14  is  higher  than  the  minority  LSE  enrollment, 
indicating that ethnic minority enrollment is lower than it should be. About 1 in 5 children do not 
complete  primary  school,  and  about  70%  of  those  dropouts  are  girls.  At  the  secondary  level, 
dropout rates are much higher in poor regions. This reflects the high contribution that education 
requires of households. Dropout data show a gender difference that is small at the LSE level but 
becomes much larger at the USE level. The reasons commonly given for dropping out of school 
are  physical  distance  from  school;  high  direct,  indirect,  and  opportunity  costs;  and  low  quality 
and  relevance  of  education.  To  increase  system  efficiency  and  the  student  retention  rate, 
education  administrators  must  be  trained  to  plan  and  manage  better  the  limited  education 
resources and to emphasize assistance policies for girls and minorities. 
 
27. 
Ineffective  Planning  for  Disadvantaged  Groups.  Data-gathering  systems  at  MOET 
and  DOET  record  total  population  and  enrollment,  but  do  not  disaggregate  data  by  district, 
ethnicity,  or  gender.  Disaggregated  data  are  needed  for  planning  and  managing  effective 
targeted  support  for  disadvantaged  groups.  Accurate  data  on  enrollment  patterns  from  an 
education  management  information  system  (EMIS)  will  enable  the  cost-effective  targeting  of 
education interventions. 
 
28. 
Limited Accountability of Local Stakeholders. In the context of the decentralization of 
responsibilities  and  resources,  MOET  is  working  to  improve  accountability  practices  to  ensure 
that resources are used efficiently and that schools and offices report the impact of such use. 

 Accountability  frameworks  hold  schools  accountable  and  compel  the  educational  system  to 
provide  key  data  for  making  decisions  and  improving  outcomes.  MOET’s  new  school  charter 
and  inclusive  school  development  plan  (ISDP)  requirements  are  intended  to  establish 
accountability by linking the school and the community in defining the school organization and 
activities.  ISDPs  cover  issues  of  school  performance  and  student  learning  outcomes  and  set 
standards  for  teachers.  In  the  majority  of  the  rural  provinces,  the  school  charter  and  ISDP 
processes are not yet participatory and seem to be undertaken more as an administrative task 
than  as  functional  planning.  Training  administrators  and  community  representatives  and 
increasing  their  awareness  of  the  use  of  ISDPs  will  improve  the  efficiency,  sustainability,  and 
accountability of education services.

3. 

Lessons Learned 

 
33. 
The key lessons learned from ADB’s experience are that successful projects require (i) a 
results-based  approach,  (ii)  project  site  selection,  and  (iii)  a  project  design  tailored  to  the 
specific needs of target areas. How the proposed project incorporates these issues is discussed 
in the Special Features section of this report (paras. 59–62). 
 
34. 
Focus  on  Results.  Many  education  projects  tend  to  set  out  vague  project  outcomes 
such as “improved quality of secondary education,” and do not have a time-bound action plan 
with monitoring indictors. More attention is paid to individual activities and inputs rather than to 
results  (e.g.,  the  project  outcome  and  impact).  For  this  reason,  although  several  large-scale 
investment projects in secondary education have been implemented successfully in Viet Nam, 
their  impact  and  outcomes  have  no  synergy  and  the  country  has  not  achieved  universal  LSE. 
The SESMP 2006–2010 analysis finds that the principal policy goal of a 90% NER by 2010 can 
be  achieved 
through  more  effective  resource  mobilization  and  strategic  pedagogical 
approaches.  
 
35. 
Geographic  Targeting. In previous ADB projects where targeted assistance was to be 
provided  to  disadvantaged  areas,  the  Government  identified  disadvantaged  areas  at  the 
province level and with a very broad geographic spread, covering almost one third of Viet Nam’s 
provinces.  The  assistance,  as  a  result,  was  spread  too  thinly—within  a  given  area  it  was  too 
small  in  real  terms  to  have  significant  impact.  Survey  data  show  marked  intra-provincial 
disparities: the education conditions in some districts belonging to relatively wealthy provinces 
are often far worse than in better-off districts in poorer provinces. However, these poor districts 
in  wealthy  provinces  were  neglected  in  past  projects,  where  province-based  target  selection 
was  the  norm.  To  provide  substantial  assistance  to  the  most  disadvantaged  groups,  project 
sites  should  be  identified  at  the  district  level  on  the  basis  of  an  integrated  assessment  of 
education, socioeconomic, and poverty indicators.

Educational  Benefits. The Project will have a substantial strategic impact on the three 
key dimensions of secondary education in the most disadvantaged regions: access and equity, 
quality  and  relevance,  and  efficiency  and  sustainability.  The  direct  benefits  to  the  sector  will 
accrue  from  (i)  significantly  narrowed  gaps  in  access  to  secondary  schooling  between  ethnic, 
gender,  and  socioeconomic  groups,  (ii)  teaching  and  learning  that  is  more  relevant  and  more 
responsive  to  local  demands,  and  (iii)  strengthened  capacity  of  local  education  authorities  to 
plan,  deliver,  and  manage  education  services.  The  Project  will  introduce,  through  the

as  CPD,  student-centered  active-learning  methods,  and  cluster  school-based  INSETT. 
Education  planning  and  management  will  benefit  from  improved  efficiency.  Internal  efficiency 
will  increase  through  reduced  pupil  repetition  and  dropout  rates  as  well  as  reduced  teacher 
turnover  (a  result  of  improved  teacher  housing).  Learning  support  through  supplementary 
instructional materials in ethnic minority languages and awareness-raising activities will improve 
learning outcomes and lower the dropout rate.

ANALYSIS OF THE EDUCATION SECTOR 

1. 
Sector Overview. In Viet Nam, education is viewed as strongly linked to economic growth 
and  it  has  been  accorded  priority  as  a  principal  investment  option  for  long-term  socioeconomic 
development.  The  central  pillar  of  the  national  education  policy  is  rapid  human  resource 
development  to  meet  the  labor  needs  of  a  highly  competitive  market  economy  within  a  socialist 
framework to ensure a high level of equity. One of Viet Nam’s advantages today is its educated, 
skilled, and low-cost workforce, but this amounts to only 27% of the national labor force, compared 
with 50% in some other developing countries in the region.1 To maintain this advantage in the face 
of regional and global competition, the Government plans to increase the percentage of the skilled 
workforce to 30% by 2007, 40% by 2010, and 60% by 2020. However, the key factor determining 
whether  Viet  Nam  will  be  able  to  maintain  this  advantage  is  whether  the  education  provided  will 
make  the  workforce  competitive  in  terms  of  the  creative  and  analytical  skills  needed  in  a 
knowledge- and technology-based industrial economy. 
 
2. 
The  importance  of  education  and  training  is  also  recognized  in  the  achievement  of 
Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDGs)  and  Viet  Nam  Development  Goal  (VDGs).  Viet  Nam  has 
already achieved poverty targets, halving income poverty and largely eradicating extreme poverty 
and  hunger.  Good  progress  has  also  been  made  toward  achieving  other  social  goals  such  as 
universal  primary  education,  gender  equality,  child  mortality,  and  maternal  health,  and  improving 
access  to  safe  drinking  water.  Progress  is  being  made  toward  combating  HIV/AIDS  and  other 
communicable  diseases,  and  mainstreaming  environment  sustainability  in  national  policies  and 
programs. 
 
3. 
Despite  these  achievements,  increased  efforts  will  be  required  to  ensure  that  key  MDGs 
related to child mortality, safe drinking water, the environment, and HIV/AIDS control are met,2 and 
to improve the quality of key services such as education. The MDGs and VDGs established several 
development targets related to education3 including: (i) universal primary education, as measured 
by  the  net  enrollment  rate  (NER),  by  2015;  (ii)  universal  progression  to  grade  5  by  2015; 
(iii) universal  youth  (aged  15–24)  literacy  by  2015;  (iv)  gender  parity  in  primary  and  secondary 
school  by  2005;  (v)  gender  parity  in  youth  literacy;  (vi)  reduced  child  mortality  and  child 
malnutrition; and (vii) reduced inequality among ethnic minorities and preservation of the ability to 
read and write in the ethnic languages. 
 
4. 
Education  and  Training  System  and  Structure.  The  national  education  and  training 
system  is  all-encompassing,  ranging  from  the  nursery  to  doctorate  programs,  and  from  formal 
schooling and training to nonformal and continuing education. There are four levels of schooling: 
(i) pre-primary,  catering  to  students  aged  3–5  years;  (ii)  5-year  primary  education  from  age  6; 
(iii) 4-year  lower  secondary  education  (LSE)  schooling;  and  (iv)  a  3-  or  4-year  upper  secondary 
education (USE) phase, where students are enrolled in either (a) an upper secondary school with a 
focus  on  higher  education,  or  (b)  a  professional  secondary  school  with  a  focus  on  vocational 
training. To ensure the achievement of an acceptable standard, some students may repeat a year, 
with  a  low  general  repetition  rate  for  lower  secondary  students  of  0.8%  but  with  marked  regional 
differences. To cater to students who drop out of school but wish either to continue their education 
in  a  less  formal  setting  or  to  qualify  for  re-enrollment  in  formal  education,  nonformal  education 
programs  have  been  established  and  operate  nationally  in  over  4,000  venues  using  a  modified 
curriculum.

9. 
Secondary  Education  and  Ethnic  Minorities.  The  Government  has  paid  attention  to 
ethnic minority education since its founding. The first constitution of Viet Nam (1946) stated: “The 
ethnic  minority  nationals  have  the  right  to  receive  compulsory  and  fee-free  primary  and  lower 
secondary  education  in  the  local  schools  by  means  of  their  languages.”  Since  then,  numerous 
decrees  and  decisions  have  been  issued  and  ratified  confirming  the  importance  of  education  for 
ethnic  minorities.  In  spite  of  these  high-level  policies,  the  outcomes  for  ethnic  minorities  in 
education  at  all  levels  remain  well  below  the  national  average.  The  accessibility  and  quality  of 
education are particularly affected by the poverty that often afflicts ethnic minority communities, as 
well as geographical isolation and other cultural barriers. 
 
Barriers  to  Education  Access  and  Quality.  Household  poverty  level  is  an  indicator  of

steady decline in poverty and have the lowest rate of poverty among the ethnic minority regions. 
Ethnic minorities in the Northern Mountain region have experienced the steadiest improvement in 
living standards, but poverty among groups in the Central Highlands has increased.4

(i) reduce  socioeconomic  barriers  for  minority  youth  in  gaining  access  to  and  completing  teacher

Program  Description.  Under  the  new  transitional  program,  minority  USS  students  (50%

student  and  $155  to  the  TTC.  The  program  will  continue  the  work  of  the  pilot,  including:  (i) 
identifying beneficiaries who meet the agreed selection criteria; (ii) conducting a tracer study for the 
beneficiary  students,  assessing  its  impact,  and  making  recommendations  for  future  scholarship

SELECTION CRITERIA AND PROCEDURE FOR TARGET PROVINCES AND DISTRICTS 

1. 
A  special  feature  of  the  Project  is  the  selection  of  the  project  beneficiary  areas.  In  the 
past,  official  development  assistance  project  areas  were  often  selected  as  “disadvantaged 
provinces”  by  the  Government.  However,  the  project  survey  shows  significant  intra-provincial 
disparities:  the  social  and  education  conditions  are  often  far  more  severe  in  some  districts 
belonging to relatively wealthy provinces than in better-off districts in poorer provinces. With the 
conventional  target  selection,  the  poor  districts  from  the  “non-disadvantaged  provinces”  would 
not  be  core  targets.  The  Project  identifies  “the  most  disadvantaged  districts”  rather  than 
provinces,  using  comprehensive  pro-poor  indicators.  As  agreed  with  the  Government,  the 
selection criteria are (i) socioeconomic indicators; (ii) education indicators; and (iii) other factors, 
such  as  availability  of  support  from  the  Government  or  donor  partners,  geographic  balance, 
priority in government policies, and priority among natural disaster-prone regions. 
 
2. 
Initial  Selection.  Two  processes  were  followed  in  selecting  the  initial  set  of  candidate 
provinces:  (i)  scoring  according  to  ranking  of  provinces  by  each  criterion;  and  (ii)  scoring 
according to absolute data for each criterion, with no ranking. A comparison of the results of the 
two  processes  gave  a  total  of  16  candidate  provinces  that  met  the  criteria  of  being 
socioeconomically  disadvantaged  and  in  need  of  assistance  in  reaching  universal  lower 
secondary education (LSE). In addition to the 16 “priority provinces,” four other provinces were 
proposed for inclusion in the list. Finally, geographic criteria were applied to ensure that there 
was  a  reasonable  distribution  of  candidate  provinces  among  the  regions:  northern  (eight 
candidates), central (seven), and southern (seven). 
 
Initial  Survey  Data.  Information  was  collected  from  candidate  districts  in  two  parts: 
3. 
(i) standard  district  data  on  population,  physical  characteristics,  and  socioeconomic  indicators 
disaggregated  by  gender  and  population  group;  and  (ii)  specific  information  on  students, 
teachers, physical facilities and equipment, etc., through a specifically designed questionnaire. 
The  data  sets  are  available  in  the  midterm  report—though  some  of  the  data  are  clearly 
inaccurate.  
 
4. 
Scoring.  The  criteria  used  to  identify  target  districts  were  basically  the  same  as  those 
used in the initial selection of provinces, with a focus on a high ratio of poor households, high 
ratio  of  communes  with  no  lower  secondary  school  (LSS),  low  coverage  of  LSE,  and  low 
enrollment figures, especially for girls, as well as gross enrollment ratio. Cleaned data from the 
survey  were  used  in  assigning  scores  against  percentage  values  calculated  from  the  data 
received from the districts. Where data for a district were missing or clearly wrong, an average 
for the other districts in the province was calculated and applied. 
 
The  percentage  of  poor  households  was  deemed  to  be  a  better  district  socioeconomic 
5. 
indicator than per capita income. In response to comments obtained during the midterm report 
workshop,  “average  distance  to  school”  was  used,  to  give  greater  weight  to  access.  In  the 
southern regions, limitations to access are a function of terrain (e.g., river crossings) rather than 
distance from the school, so scoring was designed to eliminate this variation. An additional two 
criteria  were  added  (class-classroom  ratio  and  number  of  new  classrooms  needed)  after 
discussions with Ministry of Education and Training (MOET).  
 
Final Selection of Proposed Districts. For each district, the total score obtained from 
6. 
all  criteria  was  calculated,  and  the  districts  were  ranked  in  order  of  vulnerability  (most 
disadvantaged = ranking 1; least disadvantaged = ranking 197). The final selection approved by 
MOET comprises 103 of the neediest districts in Viet Nam from 17 provinces.

The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  recognizes  secondary  education  as  one  of  the  principal  mechanisms  for  achieving 
economic  growth  and  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  The  5-year  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan 
2006–2010 targets universal  secondary  education (lower secondary  by 2010  and upper and professional secondary 
education  by  2015)  as  a  key  priority.  Special  emphasis  is  placed  on  reaching  ethnic  minorities  in  remote  areas  for 
equitable and inclusive development. Access to secondary schooling has expanded significantly in recent years, but 
national  averages  mask  significant  disparities  in  enrollment,  which  is  unevenly  distributed  by  ethnic  group,  gender, 
socioeconomic  status,  and  location.  Poverty  analysis  conducted  for  the  Secondary  Education  Sector  Master  Plan 
(SESMP) 2006–2010 shows that household income is strongly correlated with educational attainment. Ethnic minority 
youth, and particularly girls, remain the most disadvantaged in secondary education. They have for the most part not 
benefited from economic growth and poverty reduction, and risk falling further behind if secondary education remains 
out of reach. 
B. 
 
With  the  goal  of  targeting  disadvantaged  districts  in  Viet  Nam,  extensive  poverty  analysis  and  consultation  was 
undertaken,  including  (i)  a  survey  of  socioeconomic  and  education  data  from  all  districts  in  20  provinces  in  the 
regions  that  were  identified  as  disadvantaged—the  Northern  Mountain  region  (comprising  the  Northwest  and 
Northeast regions), the Central Highlands, the Mekong River Delta, and one province in the Southeast Region; (ii) an 
analysis  of  statistical  data  from  the  Government  Statistics  Office  (GSO) and  the  Ministry  of  Education  and  Training 
(MOET);  (iii) a  review  of  surveys,  studies,  and  reports  from  other  projects;  (iv)  background  work  done  for  SESMP 
2006–2010;  and  (v) field  visits  to  selected  districts  and  communes.  The  Project’s  rigorous  district-level  selection 
methodology (see Appendix 5) is unique among education projects in Viet Nam and lends the design a strong poverty 
focus. 
 
Ethnic  and  Geographic  Aspects  of  Poverty. Viet Nam had a population of more than 83 million in 2005, with an 
annual  growth  rate  of  1.4%.  An  ethno-linguistically  diverse  range  of  53  ethnic  minorities  compose  14%  of  the 
population.  For  the  most  part,  minorities  reside  in  remote,  mountainous  regions,  along  the  northern  and  western 
borders  with northeast Cambodia, the People’s Republic of China, and the Lao People’s Democratic Republic. The 
Khmer,  who  live  in  the  lowlands  of  the  Mekong  River  Delta,  and  the  Cham,  who  mostly  reside  along  the  Central 
Coast and Delta region, are exceptions. With Viet Nam’s impressive growth and poverty reduction there has been a 
shift in the locus of poverty from being widespread throughout the population to being localized in specific groups that 
are  harder  to  reach.  Minorities  are  particularly  vulnerable.  In  2004  the  national  poverty  incidence  was  26%  in  rural 
areas and 14% in urban areas (Vietnam Household Living Standard Survey 2004, based on the government poverty 
standard of D200,000 per capita per month in rural areas and D260,000 per capita per month in urban areas). There 
are  dramatic  regional  disparities  in  poverty  incidence,  e.g.,  52%  in  the  Northwest  vs.  6%  in  the  Southeast.  Poverty 
incidence in the Northeast and Central Highlands stood at 29% and 33%, respectively. Minorities compose one third 
of all poor people—the poverty gap for minorities is 19%, compared with 3% for poor Kinh. If current trends persist, 
by  2010  poverty  will  predominantly  be  related  to  ethnicity.  The  VHLSS  2004  data  confirm  that  the  smallest  ethnic 
minority groups (e.g., those with a population of less than 15,000) are also the poorest. 
 
Poverty and Education. Poverty among minority groups is closely associated with low or limited access to education 
and  training  opportunities.  The  VLHSS  2004  found  that  only  29%  of  ethnic  minority  adults  aged  18  and  over  had 
completed lower secondary education. The main barriers to access are lack of infrastructure, physical inaccessibility, 
language  and  cultural  barriers,  a  lack  of  good-quality  teachers,  a  curriculum  that  is  not  suited  to  local  needs  or 
languages,  and  high  costs  (direct,  indirect,  and  opportunity  costs),  coupled  with  the  perception  that  returns  from 
education are low. Education indicators for minorities are well below average, and lower still for minority girls. Where 
Kinh boys have 8.5 mean years of schooling, minority girls have only 4.5. Dropout rates are higher for minorities, and 
highest for minority girls. For those who can afford secondary schooling, physical distance means having to board at 
school or in private homes, at least during the week. Semi-boarding at school is particularly difficult for girls because 
of  security  and  privacy  concerns.  Sociocultural  factors  also  play  a  role  in  keeping  girls  out  of  school:  minority  girls 
tend  to  marry  early,  especially  in  the  Hmong  culture.  Many  children  drop  out  of  school  in  the  absence  of  parental 
encouragement  and  discipline,  and  when  parents  do  not  see  the  relevance  of  education  they  do  not  object.

Overview of Gender and Minority Issues in Education. The gap in socioeconomic status 
2. 
between  Viet  Nam’s  minority  groups  and  the  majority  Kinh  is  getting  wider.  Major  factors 
contributing to this disparity include: (i) geographic remoteness and challenging climatic conditions 
in  minority  areas;  (ii)  a  limited  supply  of  schools;  (iii)  a  lack  of  adequate  boarding  facilities; 
(iv) direct, indirect, and opportunity costs of secondary education; and (v) cultural factors including 
the  low  value  placed  on  education  because  of  a  perceived  lack  of  relevance,  especially  for  girls, 
who in many minorities are expected to marry at a young age. The regions of Viet Nam with large 
minority  populations  are  also  the  country’s  poorest.  While  access,  equity,  and  participation  in 
secondary  education  have  generally  improved  over  the  past  decade,  gender  disparities  are  still 
considerable,  especially  among  poor  and  ethnic  minority  households  living  in  remote  rural  areas. 
This  inequality  is  best  illustrated  by  mean  years  of  schooling,  with  girls  and  boys  achieving,  on 
average, 5.6 and 6.8 years, respectively. This gap widens dramatically when ethnicity is factored 
in:  ethnic  minority  girls  achieve  only  4.5  mean  years  of  schooling,  compared  with  8.5  years  for 
ethnic Kinh and Chinese boys.

4. 
The opportunity costs of education are considerably higher for minorities and girls than for 
boys, as shown by the participation of children aged 11–14 in income-generating activities. While 
the  percentage  of  school-aged  children  engaged  in  income-generating  activities  fell  overall 
between  1997  and  2004  as  more  children  stayed  in  school  longer,  ethnic  minority  girls  in  rural 
areas were more likely to have worked than other girls or their male counterparts. Ethnic minority 
children are twice as likely to work as Kinh or Chinese children, and ethnic minority girls are more 
likely to work than minority boys. Among the 11–14 age group, 42% of minority girls work vs. 19% 
of Kinh or Chinese boys.1 Among children aged 15–17, only 61% of minority girls are enrolled in 
school compared to 71% of ethnic Kinh/Hoa, indicating that ethnic minority girls are more likely to 
leave  school  early  for  marriage  or  income  generation.  In  2002  the  literacy  rate  for  Kinh/Chinese 
women was 92%, while for Thai and Hmong women it was 70% and 22%, respectively.

One  of  the  main  strategies  for  improving  minorities’  access  to  education  has  been  the 
establishment of boarding schools at regional, provincial, and district levels, in which all education

acquired  from  them  because  of  the  Project,  (ii) compensation  for  their  lost  productive  assets,  and 
(iii) assistance in restoring their incomes. The RF has been prepared in lieu of RPs for the Project’s 
small-scale  civil  works  (construction  or  upgrading  of  classrooms,  teacher  housing,  student 
dormitories, etc.) for which specific sites have yet to be confirmed.1 
 
Scope  of  Land  Acquisition  and  Resettlement.  In  the  selection  of  sites,  the  executing

reserved lands. This principle is contained in the loan covenants and specific assurances. However, 
the impact of land acquisition will be known only when the sites have been confirmed by the district 
and commune people’s committees, and the property boundaries have been established. All sites will 
be screened for involuntary resettlement impact. Within 6 months of loan effectiveness, a list of civil 
work sites that details land ownership and confirms the avoidance of land acquisition and involuntary 
resettlement  impact  will  be  prepared.  For  those  sites  where  involuntary  resettlement  cannot  be 
avoided,  provincial  project  implementation  unit  (PPIUs)  will  prepare  and  submit  RPs  for  review  and 
approval by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) before the award of civil works contract in each site. 
The  RP  process  includes  screening  all  land  acquisition  for  impact,  consistent  with  ADB’s 
categorization  of  involuntary  resettlement  (Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  [1995]). 2  Civil  works 
contractors  will  not  be  issued  a  notice  of  possession  for  a  site  until  (i) compensation  payment  and 
relocation  to  new  sites  have  been  satisfactorily  completed  for  the  site,  (ii)  the  agreed  rehabilitation 
assistance is in place, and (iii) the site is free of all encumbrances.

through the identification of possible alternative project designs and appropriate social,

4. 
Entitlement  Matrix. The RF contains a detailed entitlement matrix summarizing the types of 
impact,  eligibility,  and  compensation.  However,  it  may  not  cover  all  types  of  impact  but  can  be 
enhanced  in  the  RPs  depending  on  the  findings  of  the  social  assessment  and  subproject  impact. 
Standards described may not be lowered but might be enhanced in the ensuing RPs as required, and 
on the basis of detailed social impact analysis. The entitlement matrix is found in Table A16 at the end 
of this appendix, and the full resettlement framework is in Supplementary Appendix E. 
 
5. 
Socioeconomic  Information.  The  RF  prescribes  the  presentation  of  the  socioeconomic 
characteristics  of  the  APs  as  a  major  section  in  all  RPs.  The  data  on  APs  will  be  recorded  in  a 
structured questionnaire during the joint detailed measurement survey and inventory of losses in host 
communes  where  land  acquisition  will  take  place.  The  survey  instrument  will  aim  to  capture  the 
essential data on affected properties like land and other assets, ethnicity, education, income and its 
sources,  vulnerability,  gender,  and  household  population  of  APs,  among  others.  Every  detailed 
measurement  survey  questionnaire  will  be  assigned  an  alphanumeric  code  for  tracking  and 
safekeeping.  The  national  project  implementation  unit  (NPIU)  will  coordinate  with  the  respective 
PPIUs for the supervision of the joint detailed measurement survey and inventory of losses. 
 
6. 
Grievance  and  Redress  Mechanisms. The NPIU will ensure that the APs are aware of the 
procedures  for  filing  complaints  and  the  mechanism  for  redress.  Compensation,  assistance,  and 
resettlement  boards  will  help  resolve  confusion,  misunderstandings,  or  problems  about  land 
acquisition, compensation rates, rehabilitation, and relocation. The RF sets out a four-stage procedure 
for the redress of grievances that is consistent with the legal process for the resolution of disputes in 
Viet Nam. 
 
7. 
Financing Plan. All RPs will present a budget for compensation for lands, affected structures, 
other  assets,  business  incomes,  relocation  and  transfer  assistance,  crops  and  trees,  and  special 
assistance, as well as for gender development. Included in the budget presentations are the amounts 
allocated for administration cost, equivalent to 2% of the total cost of compensation and entitlements. 
All cost items in RPs will be provided with 20% contingency and will be part of Ministry of Education 
and Training’s (MOET) equity in the total cost of the Project. The financial plan for implementing the 
RPs will also be presented. 
 
8. 
Implementation Schedule and Monitoring. The Project will be implemented over a period of 
6  years.  Before  the  construction  of  civil  works  begins,  payment  for  compensation  and  provision  for 
other forms of social rehabilitation and resettlement in each site, if that be the case, must have been 
satisfactorily completed by the EA and the lands cleared of obstructions and free of all encumbrances 
before  ADB  officially  issues  its  “no  objection”  for  the  award  of  civil  works  contracts.  The  bureau  of 
education  and  training  (BOETs)  and  the  department  of  education  and  training  (DOETs)  will  ensure 
that resettlement activities do not overlap with the start of construction. All activities in RPs must be 
time-bound.  The  NPIU  and  PPIUs  will  be  jointly  responsible  for  continuous  internal  monitoring  of 
implementation  against  the  planned  activities,  time  frames,  and  budgets.  Since  only  minimal  impact 
from  land  acquisition  is  expected  from  Component  1  of  the  Project,  the  external  monitoring  of  RP 
implementation by an external monitoring agency will not be required.
